awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: Support for Self-Tracking and Patient-Provider Collaboration Using Data for Multiple and Evolving Goals in People with Migraine
awd_abstract_narration:
Technology-supported self-tracking is increasingly common across a variety of everyday domains, including finances, food, location, physical activity, time use, and weight. In the context of personal health, many patients and providers believe technology-supported self-tracking can offer a more complete, accurate, and long-term understanding. However, current tools for technology-supported self-tracking often fail to effectively support the relationship between self-tracking data and the goals that people have for that data. This project will develop new methods and tools to help people represent, manage, and track goals and their relationships to personal data. Working in the specific context of migraine-related tracking, the team will characterize patient self-tracking goals, patient-provider collaboration goals, and the implications of those goals for needs in data collection and analysis. The team will develop new methods and tools for self-tracking, based on using goal templates, as well as new methods and tools for patient-provider collaboration around these goals. The team will work closely with people with migraine and health providers in both the design and assessment of methods and tools, and will further pursue broader impacts through disseminating the methods, tools, and datasets to support others in doing self-tracking research. The project will also provide research and education opportunities for students from grade school to grad school, with the team specifically targeting students from groups that are underrepresented in computing research.

The team will characterize patient self-tracking goals, patient-provider collaboration goals, and relationships to underlying data through participatory design processes, deployments with people with migraine, and interviews and observations examining patient-provider collaborations. They will develop goal templates that scaffold the process of deciding what, when, and how to track, and will implement these templates together with appropriate analyses and visualizations in a constellation of mobile, web, and back-end self-tracking tools. They will then leverage this novel self-tracking infrastructure to examine the use of goal templates in addressing challenges of customizing tracking to a person's multiple and evolving goals, challenges of integrating tracking into everyday life, and challenges of using heterogeneous data in modeling across multiple and evolving goals. They will also examine the use of goal templates in patient-provider collaboration, including in the collaborative definition of tracking goals and in interactive curation and transformation of data according to the distinct goals and perspectives that patients and providers can bring to the same underlying data. Assessment will be conducted in field deployments, including deployments examining self-tracking by people with migraine, examining patient-provider collaborations in a specialty headache clinic and primary care contexts, and examining approaches to scaffolding of expertise for patients and providers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Major activities of the project have included: (1) iterative design of a low-fidelity prototype goal-directed self-tracking tool and use of that prototype to examine initial stages of self-tracking by people with migraine using a goal-directed self-tracking tool, (2) iterative design and development of a corresponding high-fidelity prototype for use in technology probe deployments examining later stages of self-tracking, deployment of that high-fidelity prototype in an in-the-wild examination of actual patient-provider collaboration in goal-directed tracking, (3) development of new insights and methods for modeling heterogeneous data gathered by people with evolving goals, and (4) development of new insights and methods for supporting more effective translation of research into the effective design of health-related interactive technologies.

This project characterized migraine-related tracking goals to inform a goal-directed self-tracking tool for people with migraine. It designed goal templates and scaffolding of those goals in a paper prototype of a goal-directed tracking tool, then examined the goal-directed design in a study with participants with migraine. This early prototype allowed direct observation of the "Deciding and Selecting" stage of the lived informatics model of self-tracking (i.e., participant goals and their configuration of a goal-directed tool according to those goals). This project then presented the prototype to provider participants, discussing goal categories supported by the design and exploring whether provider participants believed the system would help people with migraine and whether it would help them collaborate with and treat their patients. Participants expressed a variety of goals, and explicit representation of goals in the low-fidelity prototype supported participants in defining tracking goals that correspond to their migraine management goals.

The project then designed, developed, and examined a corresponding high-fidelity prototype, intended to enable technology probe deployments examining later stages of self-tracking (e.g., how actual goal-based tracking differs from anticipated goal-based tracking, how goals and associated tracking evolve over time, patient-provider collaboration with data obtained through goal-based tracking). The project recruited provider participants from multiple clinical contexts (e.g., migraine clinic providers, primary care providers), then each provider participant helped in recruiting several patient participants who are appropriate for self-tracking (i.e., to whom the provider would recommend tracking as part of their care). Each patient protocol included an initial interview, a corresponding initial interview with each patient's provider, observation of a joint session in which the patient and provider collaborate in setting tracking goals, a multi-week/multi-month period of patient self-tracking, a joint session in which the patient and provider collaborate to review initial data and potentially adjust tracking goals, another multi-week/multi-month period of patient self-tracking, a final joint session in which the patient and provider collaborate to review and interpret data, and a final interview with each provider based on their experiences across multiple patients. This study therefore examines goal-directed tracking in real-world care contexts (e.g., emphasizing providers and patients with existing actual care relationships), examines goal-directed tracking over an extended period that could include evolution of goals, and examines provider insights gained through collaborating with multiple different patients in goal-directed tracking.

Analyses of patient experiences with goal-directed tracking found patients were able to express multiple types of goals, to evolve their goals over time, to align tracking to their goals, to personalize their tracking, to reflect in the context of their goals, and to gain insights that enabled understanding, communication, and action. Building upon the tracker goal evolution model’s prior differentiation of so-called qualitative goals from quantitative goals, analyses differentiate management goals (e.g., states to achieve, constraints to meet) from information goals (e.g., knowledge to obtain, questions to answer) from tracking goals (e.g., a specific tracking configuration), and the project further uncovered distinct relationships among varying types of goals (e.g., alignment of management, information, and tracking goals; networks of related goals; tracking goals that address management goals without intermediate information goals). In contrast to prior models of personal informatics and goal evolution, the project’s consideration of goal-directed tracking also surfaces that an individual’s multiple distinct goals can simultaneously be in different stages of tracking (e.g., a person might complete or lapse in some goals while continuing or progressing in others). Goal expression also drove reflection, which in turn drove goal evolution. Project results directly inform the design of future goal-directed personal informatics tools, while project analyses additionally raise that future personal informatics research should account for multiple distinct and evolving goals.

Additional project outcomes include analyses of participant experiences with a Bayesian network framework for modeling symptom contributor relationships in heterogenous self-tracking data and interviews with designers and researchers regarding translational design cards to examine tensions and barriers that designers encounter, the potential for translational resources to inform the design of health-related technologies, and a need to support designers in addressing challenges of knowledge, advocacy, and evidence in designing for health.


Last Modified: 01/21/2024
Modified by: James Fogarty
